items.title: The difference between metrics and scorers
items.author: probabl
items.content:
<article>You can easily write custom metric functions for scikit-learn, but you need to take an extra step if you want to use those metrics in a hyperparameter search. To add a number there, you need to use a scorer instead. The goal of this video is to explain the difference and to show how to leverage the `make_scorer` helper utility here.

Website: https://probabl.ai/
LinkedIn: https://www.linkedin.com/company/probabl
Bluesky: https://bsky.app/profile/probabl.bsky.social

https://rss.com/podcasts/sample-space/

#probabl</article>

items.title: Introducing the CrossValidationReport
items.author: probabl
items.content:
<article>Skore version 0.6 introduces the `CrossValidationReport` that provides you with an `EstimatorReport` for each fold of your cross-validation, enabling you to inspect your estimator on each fold.

------

items.title: Remembering the order of the train_test_split
items.author: probabl
items.content:
<article>The page for the `train_test_split` function is the most visited page on the scikit-learn website. The reason, we suspect, is because folks often forget the order of arrays that come out. We know that `X_train` comes first, but then what? Is it `y_train` or `X_test`? This video explains the reasoning and also does a deep dive on the implementation.

items.title: The ups and downs of stratified cross-validation
items.author: probabl
items.content:
<article>When you use GridSearchCV in scikit-learn will do a cross-validated hyperparameter search. This is neat, but there are some worthwhile details involved when it comes to selection the cross-validation segments.

Link to discussion on Github:
https://github.com/scikit-learn/scikit-learn/issues/4757#issuecomment-2419933195

items.title: Exploring prefect for scheduling data workloads
items.author: probabl
items.content:
<article>It is easy to train a model in a notebook, but if we want to do anything with it in production we probably want to be able to train it regularly. There's good old cron, but it's 2025 now so maybe it's time to explore something a bit more modern. That's why in this livestream we will be exploring Prefect.

items.title: Playing with the classification report
items.author: probabl
items.content:
<article>In this video we will play around with a confusion matrix widget that will help us understand how the numbers in the classification report in scikit-learn are created. The classification report is a great utility, but it can help to remind oneself of what the numbers really mean. 

Scikit-learn documentation:
https://scikit-learn.org/1.5/modules/generated/sklearn.metrics.classification_report.html

Appendix with notebooks:
https://github.com/probabl-ai/youtube-appendix/tree/main/16-metrics

items.title: Introducing the EstimatorReport
items.author: probabl
items.content:
<article>Skore version 0.6 introduces a new EstimatorReport, which can be seen as a wrapper around an estimator that automatically detects all the relevant metrics and charts. The goal of the project is to be a useful sidekick for scikit-learn and you can expect more utilities to be released soon. 

Links:
skore v0.6 documentation:
https://skore.probabl.ai/0.6/index.html

skore GitHub repository:
https://github.com/probabl-ai/skore</article>

items.title: More Python parallel stuff with joblib-modal
items.author: probabl
items.content:
<article>One of the probabl colleagues has been working on an integration between joblib (which scikit-learn uses for parallel processing) and Modal (a cloud-provider known for it's likeable configuration for compute resources in Python). In this livestream we will explore a very early version and show you what's possible now and what is different. 

The notebook from this episode can be found here:
https://github.com/probabl-ai/youtube-appendix/blob/main/00-livestream/modal-jobs.ipynb

items.title: Time for some (extreme) distillation with Thomas van Dongen - founder of the Minish Lab
items.author: probabl
items.content:
<article>Word embeddings might feel like they are a little bit out of fashion. After all, we have attention mechanisms and transformer models now, right? Well, it turns out that if you apply distillation the right way you can actually get highly performant word embeddings out. It's a technique featured by the model2vec project from the Minish lab and in this episode we talk to the founder to learn more about the technique.

00:00 Introduction 
00:46 A bit of history
07:01 Benchmarks
08:44 Steps towards Model2Vec
16:06 How Model2Vec works
25:24 Tokenlearn tricks
31:17 Mention non-English
33:22 Starting Minishlab
39:21 Other projects
43:13 Future work
48:36 Outro

To learn more about Minish Lab, make sure you check out their Github repository. 
https://github.com/MinishLab

If you want to learn more about Model2Vec you can check our livestream but the Github repo is also highly recommended.
https://www.youtube.com/live/Ymn5RVaKQA0
https://github.com/MinishLab/model2vec
